number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
												The version of Battleship that's on Steam has three different modes: classic, salvo, and nuclear. Classic mode is what we're all probably used to seeing. You fire, and hit or miss, it's the opponent's turn. Salvo allows you to fire as many shots as you have ships available. In other words, if you have three ships remaining, you can fire three individual shots anywhere on the board during your turn. It's in Salvo mode that keeping as many ships afloat is crucial, as serious advantages or disadvantages can occur based on fleet size. Nuclear is a made-for-video-game mode only. In here, you have special weapons (such as torpedoes, mines, air strikes, etc) that are unlocked as you progress through the game. While the additions in Nuclear mode are neat, the problem is that the AI does not have the same restrictions you do, so it has immediate access to all weaponry. Unless you've unlocked enough weapons, you'll be at a serious disadvantage. While playing there are cutscenes when you attack with any weapon. If you miss, your shells fall harmlessly into the ocean; however, if you hit, you see your shots doing damage to whichever ship you hit. These cutscenes include special weapons in Nuclear mode, so if you launch an attack helicopter, you'll see that particular cutscene instead of the standard "turret aims and fires" scene. The graphics aren't great, but they aren't absolutely hideous either. I like that the cutscenes differ depending on weapon fired and which ship you hit. Also, the weather can change, so in one game it can be bright and sunny, and the in the next, it can be dark and stormy. So far, this is sounding like a pretty good adaptation, but there's one MAJOR problem: it's single-player only. That's right, there's no multiplayer at all. You can't play against anyone online and apparently there's no local multiplayer (aka "hotseat") available either, despite the store page specifically stating "sink enemy battleships in hotseat play." This means that whoever wrote the store's description either had no clue what they were selling or outright lied. Both possibilities are inexcusable. Battleship is meant to be a multiplayer game. Playing against the AI is okay, but most people (myself included) would've liked to play against other people and probably bought it with that assumption in-mind because the store page says there is hotseat gameplay. Fortunately, I bought this game during the Winter Sale, so while I'm still annoyed at the errors posted on the store page, at least I didn't waste money purchasing it at full price. Due to the incorrect information presented — through either carelessness or dishonesty — I'll have to give this game a NO recommendation.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												If you're looking for a simple, but still cool, single-player Battleship game, then Pop Cap made the perfect one right here. Not only does it show the use of white and red pegs to give an authentic feel to it, but also some animated radar cosmetics. You're shown some eye candy animated cutscenes with every shot for either a miss or a hit, and the background graphics comes complete with random weather and ambient sound effects. You can easily immerse yourself into the game and play for hours while trying to increase your rank. It's a very pleasant "chillaxing" type of game where everything is point-n-click super easy.I like all 3 modes of Classic, Salvo, and Super Weapon, but Super Weapon is my favorite mode. Super Weapon is probably everybody's favorite.In Classic mode it's your basic Battleship game where you and the computer take turns destroying each other. Not that much to it.In Salvo mode it's a Ship-turn-Shot game. If you have 5 ships, then you get 5 shots on your turn. Lose a ship and you lose a shot for only 4 shots per turn. Then 3, 2, and 1, if you're having a bad game. Trying to maintain 5 shots is really hard to do, but not impossible. Salvo is Salvo, that's all there is to it.In Super Weapon mode it's a Weapons-charge-Shot game. You only get 1 shot per turn, but you can really make that shot count when your weapons charge up. With one shot you can fire upon 1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 15+ coordinates, depending on what weapon you have loaded into your arsenal. There's bombers, gun-copters, shields, satellite laser beams, mines, decoy's, and a bunch of others I haven't even unlocked yet. Yes, you have to unlock most of the weapons by continuing to play the game and keep sinking enemy ships over and over, round after round. You also have to rank up to unlock some of the weapons too.The graphics are not superb, but it's good enough for this type of game.The sounds would be what you normally expect with clicks, explosions, turret effects, and other sounds matching their device or purpose. Some of the ambient sounds can get a little annoying and repetitive, but still tolerable.Now let's talk about the A.I. - It starts out rather easy and appears to be dumb at first, but after you play the game and start ranking up, the A.I. appears to match your rank and gains intelligence. It also uses a multiple random seed to pick coordinates and this is reflected with the multiple decisions you see the A.I. making before taking a shot. Seeking your ships is completely random, but after it gets a hit the A.I. will concentrate on sinking that ship with similar human intelligence. You will notice the A.I. behavior by the time you reach Captain and your usual ship configurations that used to trick the A.I. does not work anymore. That's how I know this Battleship game has an advanced A.I., and is a worthy opponent.I would recommend this game to anyone who likes board games.
